intro: Stilpnopappus pittieri, commonly known as the Mexican sunflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble a single bloom. The plant features upright, branching stems covered in fine, hairy foliage. Its vibrant orange to red inflorescences attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Stilpnopappus pittieri is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in full sun with well-drained soil.
